div.head:
56. Robert Southey and Grosvenor Charles Bedford to Charles Collins, 16 September 1793 Address: To/ Signor Carlo Collins/ at/ Captain Colquitt’s/ Pipe Grange/ near/ Lichfield/ Staffordshire/ only double
Postmark: ASE/ 19/ 93
Seal: Red wax; male figure with illegible motto
MS: Huntington Library, HM 44803 [Unusually, the letter is written on decorated stationery with a pink border patterned with blue dots; it also has a matching envelope.]
Unpublished.

lg.l: With thy breeches made of silk
And thy skin as white as milk
And thy hair so nicely drest
And thy waistcoat of the best
And thy shoes so neatly tied
And thy coat in fashions pride
What is there thou dost not know
In the meadows of Pipe Grange
Jack the secondJohannes Secundus (1511–1536), whose Liber Basiorum (Book of Kisses) was published in 1541. in thy hand
Under some elm take thy stand

On with Ovid’sPublius Ovidius Naso (43 BC–AD 17), whose works included the Amores, Heroides, Ars Amatoria, Fasti and Tristia. His surviving poems are all written in elegiac couplets, with the exception of the Metamorphoses, which is in hexameters. pretty metre
On the Pucelle of Voltaire La Pucelle (1755–1762), a mock-epic poem by Voltaire (1694–1778).
On every branch of every tree
Coming from this OrpheusIn Greek mythology, a singer whose song has more than human power. new
And the winds shall cease to blow
And the rivers cease to flow
Touchd by notes so sweet the owl
Shall in concert learn to howl
Lost in wonder look at you
And drop his eyelids soft & blue.
And the weasel there shall steal
And learn to squeak & learn to squeal
The Dolphin there in evening still
Dares the Dam of water mill.
And with open Gills the Trout
Ah! take care lest any fish
Snap thee up in luckless hour
Never JonasThe story of Jonah and the whale is found in the book of Jonah. felt such dread
Lucky whale no spur or boot
Was on, to gall thy gapeing throat
Oh may never wondering JoveIn Roman mythology, the king of the gods.
To snatch thee taking then no heed
And make another GanymedeIn Greek mythology, a handsome young boy carried off to Mount Olympus by Zeus. He replaced Hebe (daughter of Zeus and Hera) as cupbearer to the gods.
There thy hand shall fill the cup

And Captain ColquittThe naval officer Captain Goodwin Colquitt (dates unknown) was Charles Collins’s uncle by marriage. See John Nichols, The History and Antiquities of the County of Leicester, 4 vols (London, 1795–1815), IV, p. 184. gulp it up
Oh take heed wheneer you walk
Lest the eagle hear you talk
And take thee to the Gods above
To sing & play to mighty Jove
Ah take care lest any HebeIn Greek mythology, the goddess of youth.
Meet thee when the Goddess PhoebeIn Greek mythology, another name for Artemis, goddess of the moon.
Drives her ponies thro the sky
Take care lest away she run
So when once the Naiad dame
Of the font where Hylas came
Great AlcidesIn Greek mythology, another name for Hercules, father of Hylas. darling joy
HylasIn Greek mythology, one of the Argonauts. He was dragged into a spring by a water nymph who had fallen in love with him. Hylas then he cries
Out of hearing out of sight
Oh take heed my friend for fear
Some OreadIn Greek mythology, a mountain nymph. chuse thee for her dear
Snatch thee to his dismal dwelling
Then take out your neat casette
Gibbon’sEdward Gibbon (1737–1794; DNB). slyness Voltaire’s quaintness
Than these two men sure you aint less.
Cause your senses to be lost
No saw head on bloody bones
Fright thee with it’s saucer eyes
And make you dream & sleep so well
I am sure you’ll like this paper
That you like it well I ween.

div.p: make my respects to all your good Family. G.C.B.

closer.salute: make my respects to all your good Family.
